Bertram stated. "It's all black and
white to me. A man is either dead
or alive, you know."

should teach "the truth about

HULLAVA RESPONSE
Editors' Note: The following response has been offered in rebuttal
to the several criticisms directed
against this year's Hullabaloo.
You know,or you should know
if you have ever really looked,
that yearbooks are remarkably
bland publications. Traditionally
they are asexual, unemotional,
and (almost as a point of honor, if
not consistency)superficial. If you
would care to look into the embarrassing history of yearbooks
both here at Hopkins and at other
universities, there are in the Barn
decades of yearbooks which, except for the title pages, are virtually indistinguishable. They
speak of nothing in particular;t
they speak to no one in particular.
Except for changes in . style of
dress, they all could have come
out of the same time and place.
The notable exceptions among the
Hullabaloos are at the turn of the
century, when they had a distinct
character — a beautifully naive optimism about the future — and in
1964 — when Lehman and Drell
tried their hands at self-concious
media manipulation. The 1967
Hullabaloo.also is an exception.
We thought it justifiable (if we
should be called to justify it) but
even more, valuable, to make the
1967 Hullabaloo a book, a real
book, that had a subjective point
of view, that could be read, alone,
now or thirty years from now,
with the feeling that something intangible — something of what Hopkins was for us in 1967, and what
it has meant for us to be here four
years — had been captured. It was
intended to do this in an individual
way, so that if we were successful
you would find something of yourself on the pages.

In one series, the consecutive shots
of a boy and his dog are so deftly
apposed that the characters actually seem to move if you flip

nant study of the effects of Baltimore smog on the adolescent cerebral cortex may well become a

Film, through television and the movies, has come to comprise an

Film: A Creative
Compromise In Art
After completing negotiations with the Social Relations department to produce a film on game simulations, the members of the Film Workshop, under the
direction of Carl Chatzky, Ken Locker and Jamil
Simon, were left with the problem of deciding on an
approach to the film itself.
The concept of high-school students playing games
which simulate and dramatize certain aspects of their
environment presents many cinematic possibilities.
First, there is the contrast of learning through games
and through traditional methods of education. Secondly there is the contrast of situations which arise in the
games contrasted against analagous situations which
arise in real life. Within this basic structure we also
wanted to show graduate students and faculty members at Hopkins developing the games,and perhaps the
reactions of teachers using the games in the classroom.
We decided to approach the film as a documentary
shooting in synchronized sound. In order to rent two
blimped and synced cameras and an interlock tape recorder the cost came to $100 a day. At this cost, we
were able to rent the equipment for a week. Tom
Bray, audio consultant for Barton Hall, agreed to do
the sound recording for a nominal fee and to let us
use additional microphones and mixers for no charge.
In order for us to complete our shooting in this

FILM
limited period of time it was necessary to compromise
our original documentary approach and work from a
tightly organized shooting script. We decided to divide
our shooting into four parts: the graduate students
developing the game, the students playing the game, a
traditional classroom situation and the real life situations reflected in the game.
After many revisions we finally came up with a
coherent shooting script. We found that a large part of
the success of the film depended upon finding the
proper group of students to play the game. We were
fortunate in being able to arrange with John Roemer
of the Baltimore Friends School to use his eleventh
grade history class. In order to maximize the usage
of the rented equipment we decided to have several
practice sessions with the Friends School students.
Prior to our final shooting in the Clipper room of
Shriver Hall we found that in spite of its excellent
lighting, the acoustical properties made its use impossible. This turned out to be one of the major problems
we faced during the entire filming: finding rooms
which were acoustical so that we could record intelligible conversations with moderate ambient background noise.
Our second major problem, especially with the
high school students, was to obtain dialogue that didn't
sound unnatural or unduly stilted. In order to overcome this problem we again had to compromise certain aspects of our script. We found that in order to
maximize the spontanaity of the dialogue we. were
forced to abandon a strict script with a precise and
preplanned dialogue. In effect our shooting sessions
turned out to be small waiting games. The sound
cameraman was sitting in a wheel chair with the camera assistant waiting behind him poised and ready to
move at the director's signal. Tom Bray devised a
rather unique communications system between the
cameraman,director and soundinan. The director(Carll
Chatzky, the cameramen (Ken Locker and Jamil Simon)and the soundmen(Tom Bray and Fred Portnoy)
were all able to listen to the sound as it was being recorded; the director, through the use of a small micorphone was able to talk to the camera man, telling
him when and where to shoot, and to his sound man,
telling him which microphone to fade in and out on.
All of this could be done without disturbing the actual playing of the game without distracting conversations among the technical crew.

In the past few years, experimentation has been going on with
a new kind of tool for learning - educational games. Hopkins' Dr.
James Coleman, Professor of Social Relations, has been a leader

Dr. Coleman refers to this learning tool as "using highly structured
games for learning at all levels of
education and for learning in a
wide variety of environments."
Students playing the game, thus,
"learn not by formal teaching, but
by acting in an environment created by the rules of the game."
The games "are designed to extract from the complex world of
reality a particular fragment of the
environment," he adds."The player then finds himself coping with
that fragment."
For example, in playing a democracy game, students learn how
the system of representative democracy functions by acting out
the role of a legislator. They better
understand the complexity of
government and the role of a legislator in that fragment of their
environment.
Most of the simulated-environment games which have been constructed are in the field of the Social Sciences.. Besides the democracy game, there is an international simulation game, a consumer economics game, a life career
game, a game simulating the conditions of England during the Industrial Revolution, a parent-child
game,a community action game, a
propaganda game, an economic
system game and others.
Children often achieve more
"learning in an environment" than
they do with formal teaching. Dr.
Coleman cites the learning of a language as an example of learning in
an environment. He adds that
many children who learn something as complex as language while
in an environment may have trouble learning much simpler things
while in school. "The cause may
well be," he states, "that being
taught in school is simply not as
effective fof learning as are the
environments within which they
learn to talk."

games in the classroom is motivation. No one has to push students
into playing. More often, they
push reluctant teachers into letting them play.
Another major problem in the
classroom which the games may be
able to eliminate is that of the conflict between the teacher's role as
Judge and helper. In a normal situation, one of the teacher primary functions is to give marks.
Dr. Coleman believes that "As a
result, students develop attitudes
toward the teacher that can greatly interfer with learning: hostility,
servility, alienation . "
But simulated - environment
games are self-judging. The player
knows he has won or lost by his
own actions. The teacher need no
longer be the judge, but instead
can serve as a helper to all of the
Players.

for the poorly motivated student.

Film, through television and the movies, has come to comprise an

scholars'and educating citizens, film study in the university opens a

After completing negotiations with the Social Relations department to produce a film on game simulations, the members of the Film Workshop, under the
direction of Carl Chatzky, Ken Locker and Jamil

approach to the film itself.
The concept of high-school students playing games
which simulate and dramatize certain aspects of their
environment presents many cinematic possibilities.
First, there is the contrast of learning through games
and through traditional methods of education. Secondly there is the contrast of situations which arise in the
games contrasted against analagous situations which
arise in real life. Within this basic structure we also
wanted to show graduate students and faculty members at Hopkins developing the games,and perhaps the
reactions of teachers using the games in the classroom.
We decided to approach the film as a documentary
shooting in synchronized sound. In order to rent two
blimped and synced cameras and an interlock tape recorder the cost came to $100 a day. At this cost, we
were able to rent the equipment for a week. Tom
Bray, audio consultant for Barton Hall, agreed to do
the sound recording for a nominal fee and to let us
use additional microphones and mixers for no charge.
In order for us to complete our shooting in this

our original documentary approach and work from a
tightly organized shooting script. We decided to divide
our shooting into four parts: the graduate students
developing the game, the students playing the game, a
traditional classroom situation and the real life situations reflected in the game.
After many revisions we finally came up with a
coherent shooting script. We found that a large part of
